title: High expectations, disappointing reality
pros: Brilliant, hard-working team members. Remote work allows for slightly more flexibility than a typical 9-5 job. The material the team puts out is world-class and top-notch. Most team members are incredibly helpful and kind. Monthly education and tech reimbursement that, while small, is helpful.
cons:
Oh man, I'm so sad to write this review. I've been a customer of the company myself since 2010, having spent $1,000+ of my own money on the products (and I've gifted the book to 5+ people). Joining the team I had high expectations and loved the company company, but after I left I was incredibly disappointed during my 2+ years with the organization. Here's why:

* Compensation is below industry standards, as seen for multiple positions and compared to data found on Glassdoor, Payscale, and Salary.com. Even after negotiating multiple times, the company rarely budges and I was paid 5-10% below market rate.

* In the 2 years I was there, there was only 1 title promotion given to an employee. You likely won't ever have the chance of a title change which is the very definition of a "dead-end" job.

* More and more team members are coming in who are unfamiliar with the company's products, especially at the executive level. The company is on the path to becoming a product factory where quality decreases just for the sake of more revenue. Meetings are now focused on "how much money did we make, how can we optimize the sales funnel?" instead of "what good are we doing for the world?" We saw this with a recent product where refund rates and dissatisfaction was abnormally high -- and I think this trend will continue.

* There's a clear divide developing between a high-ranking executive member and the rest of the organization. This dissatisfaction is real, and I think it will lead to a lot of really good leaders and team members leaving over the next few months.

* The are no volunteer or "giving back" opportunities supported by the organization. If you just want to work for a company that's focused on money, this may be the job for you. But if you want to work for a company where you have the chance to become more well-rounded and do good for the world, this probably isn't it.

* For a company that compares itself against San Francisco startups, their benefits package is extremely weak. Most startups now offer unlimited vacation, free movie passes, stock options, free meals, and more. I Will Teach You to be Rich does none of this (and their 401(k), while mostly strong, requires a LONG vesting period for company match).

* For most positions, it's a requirement to track time. This shows an overall lack of trust the company has in employees. I felt more micromanaged and tracked than I have in any other job I've been in.

Overall, I wish I Will Teach You to be Rich was a better company to work for. During the 2 years I was there, I felt mostly disappointment and saddened by the realities of working for the company. I'll continue to be a customer of their products but, when asked, I've told people they should not work there and will continue to do so.

title: Amazing Opportunity for the Right Person
pros: The company went through a rough patch a few years back, and they've worked hard to rebuild and change the way they do things. The environment and business structure is very different than it was a few years ago, and the same goes for the attitude of the management. They are hyper-focused on being an industry leader and producing high quality, high value products. For the ambitious individual, there are lots of opportunities for promotions and career development. Also many opportunities to gain skills in a wide variety of areas. The projects are exciting, the pace is fast, and you can do it all from the comfort of your own home (if that's your thing). Compensation has always been more than fair. Also, they expect you to work HARD, which I personally found refreshing. The standards are high, and if you are half committed, or just want to clock it in, it will get noticed and be addressed. Personally I respect management for this and I like the challenge of working hard. The CEO is a visionary, and the content he and the team produces truly is excellent. It feels good to work for a company whose products you stand behind and believe in.
cons: The hours are not quite flexible as advertised. While you don't have to work M-F, 9-5, you also can't veer too far from it because you have to attend meetings and communicate with team members usually during those hours. Also, working from home is not for everyone. You are more isolated and less connected than you would be in an office. A lot of people love this independence but again it's not for everyone. Since the brand is highly connected to the CEO as a person, the line is sometimes blurred between which decisions are his personal call and which are business decisions open for debate. This can be frustrating at times.

Must work late at night to make any money (at least until 930-10) because most clients are teachers in California.  Saturdays and some Sundays required,  Constant write-ups for sales reps.  Can't keep staff, almost 100% turn-around. Class training is over six weeks and is not realistic for when you are ready to work on the sales floor. Sick days are a benefit but if you use them you get written up for not being dependable. Tedious interview process (expect three to four interviews in all, and 2 hours per interview) CC has the worst IT of any company I have ever worked for, systems constantly down, internet very slow, freezing, can't log in, etc.

title: Great pay, Poorly Managed
pros: Company's pay structure is above average for the industry. Pressure from first-line managers is minimal, and  there is a fair amount of autonomy afforded to the adjuster to make decisions that benefit both the insureds and the company. One of the few companies that doesn't require a college degree to gain entry into the field.
cons:
Benefits are quite expensive, and the 401k match could be a bit more generous. Most competitors offer a match on the first 6%; we are at 4%. Business improvements happen at less than a snail's pace. It takes years to get seemingly simple and cost-neutral policies enacted. Senior management has little experience outside of California Casualty and their way of doing things. First-line managers often have little to no experience in the day-to-day handling of claims. First-line managers are often hired from the "outside" meaning there is little if any advancement possibility at the company. Once you are in a position, expect to leave, retire, or die in that same position. Technology is roughly 10-12 years behind the rest of the industry. 
Any real improvements/suggestions offered by the employee receive little more than lip service though, many of these same suggestions are eventually adopted and senior management takes all the credit. In short, no one, I mean NO ONE in management listens to their employees.

title: Love it here!
pros: I've been with California Casualty for over 15 years and in that time, I have watched many changes occur in the organization.  I've read some of the previous reviews and I'm really surprised by how angry some people seem to be.  Yes, the company has changed over the years, but we can't keep doing things the same way and expecting to stay in business.  This really is a great company to work for.  Management does care about its employees and appreciates the longevity of is staff.  I've had many positions in my 15+ years and have really enjoyed growing and learning.  Do I love every change that has been made here? Of course not!  But, I'm not running the show and I don't have the knowledge or experience to do so either and I believe that changes made are for the future of the company and its employees.  It doesn't negate the positives of working here.  If you are a good employee and do your job, you will have a really successful career here.  If you want your own way and are a complainer, then please look elsewhere.
cons: I don't love how much the healthcare coverage costs, but I recognize that the company takes the majority of  the increases in premium and that this is an issues everywhere.  It is great health coverage.  Our IT systems are antiquated and it seems we just keep putting band aids on things.

title: Great Opportunity if you're Disciplined and like to be Micromanaged!
pros: Benefits, pay, and commission are competitive compared to industry standards and great coworkers. Stay disciplined and on the phones and you'll make lots of $$!
cons: Worst micromanaging I've ever experienced. If I didn't make money here, I would have left a long time ago. Management is constantly monitoring your calls, writing you up for the tiniest of infractions, and anytime someone from another department sends you an email, they copy your manager on the email. Zero trust between management and sales reps. I understand if someone is a new hire and needs help but after you've been here for several years, the managers still sit in your cubicle with you and listen/critique calls. I imagine this is why the outbound sales dept has such poor attrition.

title: Sales
pros: I have worked for California Casualty for many years.   Seen many "ups" and a few "downs" as any company experiences over the course of several decades.   This Enterprise has a palpable heartbeat and a great compassion and care for the customers it serves and for the fellow employees who work here.   The front line sales employees overall demonstrate a refreshing commitment to the members/customers on a daily basis.   They also help each other out even though their is friendly competition amongst each other.    Management does their best to support and nurture them, and abide by the Code which was established back in 1965.  I feel that each member of the management team has their employees best interest in their respective hearts. There is a lot of teamwork and care between all the employees in Sales- which helps our tenure and experience level in an environment (sales in general) that normally has higher turnover.     The intimate private family owned company environment is refreshing as well. You are not a number here... you truly can and do make a difference to the overall results of the Enterprise.
cons: Our IT support is stretched and challenged by systems that are in the process of being modernized and updated.  For a relatively smaller company, this can be a huge challenge and the updates sometimes seem to come rather slowly.

title: Love it
pros: Comfortable environment to work in
cons: There are no cons here

title: Micromanaging
pros:
Pay is Decent
Holidays off
Good benefits
cons:
no room for growth
micromanagers
Not flexible

title: Insurance
pros: Easy work environment to be in.
cons: Leadership lacks within the organization.

title: California Casualty really cares..... That's why I love working here.
pros: I’ve worked at California Casualty for 3 years. One of the things I just love about working here is they really care about you. The management takes a personal interest in all of us and they are always showing us how much we are  appreciated. That is such a rare find in a company today. The CEO, Beau Brown, regularly comes to our facility and personally takes the time to talk to everyone individually. It’s that kind of personal touch they show every single day that makes it a special place to work.  They have assembled an amazing group of people that truly care about this company and our customers, myself being one of them.
cons: The only con I could come up with is that we are a little behind the times as far as technology goes. They have made huge strides in that since I started but we still have a long ways to go.

title: A good company that disappointed
pros:
1. Being a smaller company(compared to other insurance companies), you feel less like a warm body answering phones and being tracked.
2. The experience gained would be helpful to people wanting a variety of claim types as you will handle many kinds to varying degrees. 
3. Pay is pretty good.
4. Hours are standard Mon-Fri with around 10 days off between holidays and free personal days per year.
cons:
1. Benefits got worse every year.
2. High turnover(which is unfortunately normal for this industry)
3. Management changed the phone system to a full time queue system, meaning every claims adjuster was available to answer status calls all day from anyone who called. They still expected you to also complete your own assigned claims at the same time.
4. Management repeatedly stated if the queue system didn't work, they would change it. They only made it worse but refused to remove it.
5. The claims software, although new, was poorly implemented. If there was one issue, the entire company's system would crash and burn. Makes having multiple offices pointless.

title: Proven to not be your typical call center - time and time again!!!
pros:
Work/life balance is a hot topic now amongst the workforce.  This is just one of the advantages of working for Cal Cas.  The work week is 37.5 hours and we are closed most major Holidays.  There are lots of tenured employees; the average tenure of a customer service representative is a little over 15 years.  To some, this may be seen as a limit of growth opportunity.  However, as long as you have a solid development plan in place and a good foundation; when an opportunity becomes available you can secure it as long as you don't let it pass you by.  There is truly a family atmosphere amongst everyone; we all care for one another on a professional and personal level!  Our customer base is also one built amongst professionals so that leads to a better customer experience for all!

If you are looking for a positive, significant & rewarding change in your career life - then check out Cal Cas!  This will be the best decision of your professional path and growth!
cons: I do not have any!

title: It has been an amazing ride!
pros: I've worked at California Casualty for 14 years and it has been a great experience.  No company is perfect, but what I can say is that the company really cares about its customers AND employees.  There is a lot of tenure in the organization with many employees working here 20+ years.  The executives are great.  Most know and interact with employees regularly.  The Chairman and CEO, Beau Brown, literally knows everyone here by name.  Seriously, where are you going to find that at another company?  This truly is a family and I'm proud to be a part of it.
cons: Because we are a small company, promotional opportunities are slim.  However, the company does try to find ways to grow you in your position with challenging assignments, projects, etc.  Also, we tend to try and fix our IT systems internally, because they were created internally.  I think we could do better, by improving our technology with something we didn't create ourselves.

title: Customer Service
pros: Great atmosphere. Wonderful customers. Incredibly low stress compared with previous jobs I've had. You get a monthly review of stats and 4 quality scores but no tedious weekly coachings that make you feel awful because the entire point is meant to point out how you suck. That doesn't happen here so it's a huge relief not to be micromanaged.
cons: Sick time is generous, vacation time is accrued much less. If you use sick time though, it's going to count against you and there aren't the same standards for managers and reps.

title: My employees make the difference!
pros: The people are the number one reason why I stay at CalCas.  My team is the best!  They celebrate each other's birthdays, organize breakfast potlucks on payday, adopt families at Christmas, and are genuinely interested in each other's lives.  They care passionately about their work, and support each other when they are falling behind or handling a difficult customer situation.  They let their personalities shine in their internet-based interactions with our customers, and receive compliments daily on our Click to Chat surveys about their efficiency, knowledge and compassion.  I am excited to come to work every day to partner with them to achieve their personal career goals, our team goals, and ultimately our corporate goals.
cons: We are a small but mighty team.  We handle e-commerce, snail mail, faxes, outbound calls, inbound calls, walk-in customers, and more.  We need to continue to try and find the right balance for these often competing priorities.

title: California Casualty is a great place to work - It is solidand rich in history; The best managers on the planet are here!
pros: Upbeat, enthusiastic environment.  People enjoy working here and it is evident as you meet the individual employees - smiling, happy, and still work hard daily to achieve goals.  Great management that are friendly, caring and want you to succeed to be the best you can be.  The customers are public servants and that makes every customer contact a much higher quality than those who work with the general public.
cons: There are no Cons - I love everyting about it.

title: Great company to work for!
pros:
Company car and fuel card
Work from home when not in the field
Above average salary
Opportunity for monetary bonuses
Make your own schedule
Getting paid to travel your home state instead of sitting in a cubicle
Meet new people every day
Open door policy even when working in the field
Fair management
Challenging enough to keep me from getting bored
Bonus trips
Plenty of room to advance your salary in a fairly short amount of time
Recognition to employees that go above and beyond
Promoted to be creative and have fun on the job
cons:
Goals can be challenging but goals are constantly being looked at by management and changes are made when something is not working well
Every once in a while have to work above normal hours to reach goals

title: Great company to work for!
pros: This is a wonderful company that is dedicated to its customers, employees, and bottom line (in that order). The most important aspect of business at CalCas is to treat the customer (insured) with honesty and respect. Employees are treated like family at California Casualty. An employees' safety is paramount. California Casualty knows and lives the philosophy, "if you take care of others, they will in return, take care of you".  It is one thing to hear a company "talk" about putting customers and employees first; it is another thing to experience the words put into action. Existing employees are excited to welcome new hires and offer help at every turn. The work environment feels inclusive and optimistic. I can't say enough great things about California Casualty!
cons: Honestly, none that I can think of.......I've been working here about 5 months so far.

title: Understaffed, Underpaid, and Overworked
pros: The coworkers are great because they all feel you like do. Its a casual environment.  The CEO Beau Brown is the nicest guy you'll ever meet but he doesn't have anything to do with running the claims department.
cons: You will be micromanaged on everything you do. The only way you will ever get caught up is if you work 50+ hours a week. Tenured employees take all the vacation time and early schedules so don't count on either of those. Systems are 20 years old and they refuse to update them. There is zero chance of a promotion to another role as there are 20 year employees still in the same position they were hired in.

title: Great company, great CEO, bad frontline management.
pros: Pay is decent for the industry. Great mission statement. Love the opportunity to assist American heroes in making financial decisions.
cons: Management creates a terribly stressful work environment. Management has no trust in employees. Constantly listening in on phone calls or sitting directly behind you in your cubicle breathing down your neck while talking to customers. How is this conducive to success? Let the sales reps thrive by trusting them. If underwriting doesn’t have time to process your applications for the month, you simply don’t get paid for them and will get “written up” for not hitting your goal, even if you sold enough policies. Corporate is disconnected from the reality of how this office operates. Constantly having to hire new employees yet can’t seem to figure out why.

title: Good opportunities for me
pros: I have had a great work experience at California Casualty.  I've been given challenges and opportunities to grow and try new things.  I have a great manager and I believe that the company's ethical standards are very high.
cons: It's a family owned business, so there are limits for many things.  We aren't ever going to compete with Geico or Allstate.   There have been staffing cuts and budget cuts over the years that are difficult to deal with.  But if you can be creative in how you approach your workload, there is always a way.

title: Family Friendly
pros: Great  people to work with, good pay and caring management. Everyone is kind and supportive, lots of potlucks, treats and luncheons. Management interacts well with employees.
cons: There is no for advancement and everyone has the same job  title and nearly the same pay. There is no separation from an employee who doesn't perform to an employee who over achieves in their position. The bonus plan is hard to achieve and goals are unrealistic on a long term basis. There is no flexibility in scheduling, no telecommuting, job sharing or part time schedules offered. There are no vacation trades or buy outs and getting time off is non existent if you don't plan your time six months in advance.  If you use your accumulated and available sick time you are reprimanded and ostracized for it. Cost of benefits per month is high.

title: Best career decision!
pros: The company culture is very much like a family as we all support each other. There is a fun vibe with a casual environment.  There is plenty of opportunity to advance if you are driven. This is a solid company and I am happy to head into the office and see co-workers that are more like friends. And yes, our CEO does know your name and is a really nice person. You will see a combination of hard-working, bright people that are also caring. Yes, the combination exists at this company. If you are looking for a sales position, you can have a huge career here. There are sales consultants with 15 and 20 years of tenure.
cons: Sometimes resources are limited, but CalCas has key people in the correct positions to solve issues.

title: The best Company on the Planet
pros: This company is awesome.  They value their employees and create a great work enviroment.  Beau Brown is the fourth generation owner of his family for our company, and one of the greatest CEO's that any organization has ever had.  He knows all employees by name and makes everyone feel special and like they are important and they matter.  This is a company you would never want to leave, should  you be lucky enough to get to work here
cons: There are no cons as this is the company is perfect!

title: Not a career-oriented company
pros: This is a small company so it is very easy to get to know people.  Most of the employees are eager to help you learn and answer questions.
cons: Due to it's small size, there is very limited flexibility.  I was unable to get time off that I had requested six months in advance.  There is a very tight work schedule that is not conducive at all to family needs and I found a significant lack of work/life balance.  Scheduling and promotional opportunity is extremely limited due to the amount of tenure most of the employees have.  Anyone new coming in will not have seniority for time off or upward movement for at least five years.

title: This is the best company I've worked for!
pros: The atmosphere is great! Everyone is always smiling and the positivity all around is very uplifting and motivating.  The executives and upper management do a great job of interacting with everyone and being approachable.  They encourage employees to make decisions and it's even OK to make a mistake every once in awhile.  The tenure among the employees is also very impressive; there are people going on 20-30+ years with the company and that's not something you see very many places.
cons: Being a smaller company, there aren't a lot of opportunities for movement up the ladder.  They do try to provide opportunities to develop skills and participate in other activities outside of your regular scope of responsiblities, which is appreciated. The technology and systems are a bit behind the times, which can make doing certain things challenging and more cumbersome.

title: Love CalCas!
pros: California Casualty offers us a great environment to work in, company is very professional yet casual and comfortable.. Management is family oriented, caring and welcome suggestions, listen and make changes that help the flow of business when possible. Pay is great, hours for FT great and lots of snacks a little spiffs make it fun. I've worked here over 3 years  and can't say enough wonderful things about the management team and CalCas!
cons: Been waiting to go part time for over 3 years and No part time positions in the Customer Service Department offered.  Not too many choices with Medical Insurance Plans/high deductibles. .

title: Great Company, Leadership, & Income Potential!
pros:
-Compensation plan is very competitive with the rest of the industry and top sales rep make over $100K

-Company pays for your P&C licenses in 44 states

-Team Managers in Leawood,KS office are very helpful and will do everything they can to help you succeed. 

-Hours are very flexible and, for the most part, you make your own schedule
cons: -A lot of the initial training was not hands-on, as the trainer was located in another state and you were basically taught through a TV screen. This sometimes made it difficult to hear the instructor and communicate with them. However, my training was about 2 years ago and I believe the company has improved on their training process since then.

title: Kansas and Colorado Service Center- Outbound- Great Opp
pros: You control your day...   if you put in the proper work during your 37.5 to 40 hour scheduled week, you definitely can reap the rewards.  Excellent income potential that comes with the production.   You have to dial on your leads and get in front of customers.  This is completely doable, but you have to be responsible for yourself and complete the activities.      Flexible work schedule, your team leader will work and has good supportive team atmospheres in both locations.     The people are awesome in both locations.   Quality.
cons: No cons if you are disciplined to the process and work the leads.

title: Proud to represent such an excellent company who cares about their community and customers!
pros: You have the freedom and flexability to manage your groups and territory to meet assigned goals. The company creates marketing promotions that will in some way benefit the groups/ communities we serve such as our Athletic Grants, Nominate a Hero etc. We are encouraged to submit sugestions and ideas directly to Sr Management.
cons: It is still a job and we must meet performance expectations. Based on our monthly reports they are attainable with a majroity being able to surpass the minimum standards.

title: California Casualty (claims) is not your every day 9-5 job!
pros:
Working at Cal Cas offers a variety of day to day claims handling. This allows personal growth and positive challenges that a mundane 9-5 position may not offer. I enjoy that after 14+ years with Cal Cas, I am still able to come to work and learn something new each day.
Cal Cas offers competitive wages, on-going education (for those interested in pursuing), and state mandated testing for claims handling.
cons: Cal Cas is a smaller company, permanent advancement does take time however, management is aware of those that are looking to progress their careers with the company.

title: Torn between staying or leaving
pros: Calcas makes you feel important and more then just a number. The hours of operation are great. The pay is on par with other similar positions in the industry. There are Managers that are very effective at their roles and do a good job of listening to their employees (for the most part). The CEO knows everyones names and back stories and seems genuinely interested in the employees. Same goes for other VP's/ higher up managers.  It is hard to explain all of the pros unless you have worked here and do not get me wrong, this is a good place to work, if you can over come the pros listed below
cons:
The push to sell has become has become as, if not more, important then the quality of service being provided to our patrons. Many parts of the sales process are out of the hands of the employees (can the sales dept close the sale, can u/w issue the sales etc), and when employees both current and former have expressed concerns about this metric, they are met with a canned response from someone in leadership (please see prior reviews for examples).
Instead of looking for alternatives, that reinforce the behaviors of offering new products, Calcas is  focusing on the number of issued sales, this is not fair to the employees!

Another issue is the staffing, or lack thereof. Calcas is nearly always slammed with calls due to being understaffed  or due to employees attendance, and we are now being cross trained to help other departments that are struggling to keep up with the amount of work they have. I understand the need to keep expenses low, but where is the line between cost effective and being cheap? 

There is very little "growth" in the company. There are several employees on the phone that have been with the company since 1980. This is due to the company being so small. Not sure if that is pro or con..

title: Penny Wise Dollar Dumd
pros: This is a great company with a strong family owned culture. You will feel and be treated like family. The CEO will know you by name. The company is very directionally correct by relating high level company goals to your individual contribution. The people make this a positive place to work overall!
cons:
They focus so much on saving money and being frugal it seems there is a financial struggle although they have one of the strongest rankings for capital. The cost of health insurance for the employee is extremely high, the high deductible plan makes it hard to go to the doctor, the annual sales recognition event was removed, the pension plan was frozen (replaced with a savings investment plan but a hit to long term employees), small coffee cups instead of a tad bigger coffee cups, you get the idea. All the perks for employees have been stripped away 

There is high scrutiny on home inspections making it very difficult for their members to obtain home insurance. Members are cancelled for a missing shingle or  they ask members to paint their homes in the winter. Common sense seems to be set aside in order to fix a number on a report somewhere. The risk is that they damage the affinity group marketing brand in the process and do not have a growing opportunity with new groups to market. It feels like this plan has a dead end instead of a recovery.

title: Great career change!
pros: I love my job! I love helping others even though  the reason they are calling is never positive. It's nice to be able to assure customers no matter the circumstances, CalCas will be on our customers side and do everything we can to turn their bad situation into a good experience. Management is great, I have the best TM. I've never worked in this industry before, but I love it and don't plan on going anywhere else. Great schedule, great pay, great training staff (All questions are answered quickly and professionally). Team environment, friendly coworkers.
cons: Benefits are quite expensive with a high deductible.

title: This used to be a great company, but management has really caused micromanaging to overdue common sense.
pros: This used to be a great company that cared about its employees.
cons: The new trend to not just manage risk but to attempt risk elimination. That has caused managers to run over good employees and overlook any job performance that does not exactly align with the idealistic expectations thar come out of their endless meetings. Making your goals, having your customers love you and trust you is not enough to save your job if you don't look like management and if you are not a part of their close minded culture.

title: Fabulous and rewarding place to work.
pros: Family owned, employees are treated with respect and valued, great work environment. There is also great HR and Learning and Development support for work place issues or for those who want to advance. I am six months in and feel valued, challenged and appreciated. No place is perfect but I have talked with many people here who left other work environments to join California Casualty, and what more can you say about a company that boasts hundreds of employees with 25 years or more who still work here.
cons: Expectations are high but attainable.

title: Not all change is for the better.
pros: Flexible for parents with children. Pay is good. Nice surroundings and easy commute. Employees are freindly to one another. Long term employees.
cons: Exec Mgmt shifted to younger group and they're inexperience is showing. Make changes for the sake of making changes - trying to make thier mark. Health and retirement benefits have been reduced. Communication is poor and it now has the high school clique feel to it.

title: A realistic viewpoint
pros: Company is small enough that you can easily gain recognition for accomplishments and results.  Starting salaries are competitive and performance bonuses are provided at many levels.  Their code is well written and when followed, provides an excellent culture to work within.
cons: Your success and work experiences depends on which department and which manager you work under.  There are three service centers, one of which has consistently shown poor leadership and work environment and as a result, incurs large layoffs.  One department  to which out for is claims.  Leadership from the top down displays chaotic behavior and inconsistent values.  If you choose to work in claims, make sure you probe deeply to determine what kind of environment you enter.  The company is shrinking and continues to push cost cuts over profit and market growth.  Claims just went through a round of layoffs in the field area and it appears this trend will continue, so job uncertainty is evident.  You will also find situations where you can be terminated for one instance (non-egregious) without warning while other units allow similar situations to continue without consequence.  The company touts  due process when dealing with discipline issues, but in reality, many terminations are decided by a claims management committee and outcomes are often decided based on personal biases and not objective reasoning.  Job rotations are mandatory and are pushed on you whether you want them or not and without a written development plan.  In a two year period, you can find yourself with two, sometimes three different managers who are rotated.    These are just a few examples and many more exist.  Be careful

title: Great people from management on down!
pros: California Casualty goes the extra step to insure they hear their employees and customers. IT Sinsurance...it's not fun for anyone...it's a necessity and this company and the people I work with are great... family friendly and professional and fair.
cons: No part time and limited flex hours due to company needs. Summers are busy so hard to take any extended time off.

title: Good Company and Great Training
pros: Really good company serving first responders, educators and nurses. The training was excellent and maybe the best in my career! H,R. Dept is excellent as well.
cons: Pay structure is weak and needs to be strengthened. It is mostly minimum wage with some salary and no residual income.

title: Claims Adjuster
pros: It's a small atmosphere so not like a busy call center. You have time to work your claims. Unlike other companies, the call volumes and the workload is manageable. Even with their change to an all day queue system, I actually can't wait to be able to make my calls and do my work when I need to! There's other opportunities to grow as a claims adjuster here since you handle auto, injury and property claims. The variety makes the day go by fast. I actually have a great manager who knows her stuff. The other employees have been here a long time, so they've done their time and they have awesome experiences and knowledge. Sure, I've heard them talk about me, too, but once I've mastered their systems and handled the claims in a consistent way, I'm sure that will stop. Don't let it get to you. It's just a job and there's plenty of work to focus on. Time off is hard to get when competing with high seniority, but that comes with any company that someone is new to. Some of the employees have their kids stay with them at their desk, so this is a company that understands when parents are in a bind with daycare, etc. ~ you don't find that at other companies! The customers can be difficult, but this is an industry where people are upset and not always happy with your decision. As for the older customers, I find them a delight to talk with and they are the first ones to make me feel good about what I do for them. Also, the pay is great! Maybe not the benefits, but then, in today's work environment, what company is delivering awesome benefits anymore? This is a great change for someone who has done claims at other companies. You can bring your experience and build on it, once you get past their systems. If you're new, I would think this is a great place to learn, too. Every new adjuster struggled and felt overwhelmed their first 2 years. If you can get past that and focus on the work, you'll actually find some enjoyment in it.
cons: Systems are outdated and hard to maneuver through. My only concern is it affects my body. Lots of repeat steps to accomplish something and it's taking its toll on the hands and arms. It's a small company so they don't have the means to improve their systems right now, but it does sound like an excuse when they say that every time. As employees, we don't like excuses any more than leaders like to hear them from their workers. At least acknowledge it and get a plan in place to work on or solve the problem in the future (even if it is a 2-5 year plan). Otherwise, you (the leaders) run the risk of being considered "part of the problem". I do miss having a company that supports getting your AIC or CPCU or SCLA. Wish there was some sort of incentive to pursue this, even if it was "performance based". Just like seniority earns you the pick of time off, I wish my performance would allow me the "pick" of classes the company would sponsor.

title: Amazing company!
pros: I have never worked for a company where the CEO walks around and speaks to EVERY employee and remembers them by name! My direct manager coaches me daily and is always full of positive feedback. The atmosphere is so warm and it's as if we are all a family! This is a job I wish I would of landed years ago!!!
cons: I honestly have no cons

title: No just another job, but a career with a Family.
pros:
I was immediately attracted to California for their long history and their reputation in the insurance industry. California Casualty has been around for over 100 years and it's not just a coincidence that they have such a solid reputation to the members they insure. They are family owned business and values work-life balance. 

From a personal perspective, I have the ability to work out in the morning or spend time with my family earlier in the day before going into work. This has greatly helped my family and I am very thankful that my schedule allows me to do this.

From a sales representative perspective, you have so many resources and tools to your disposal to be successful. They have comprehensive training so that once completed you can run with the bulls and immediately start selling. 

There are plenty of leads assigned to you and there are enough that there are no issues when it comes to "not having enough". 

Management is great, they give you plenty of room for you to succeed but will always be available to offer any training you need. You have one manager who is very technical and very detailed about specific requirements needed if you are stuck with a specific client. On the other hand, you have the newest manager who has been in the field for over 15 years and brings a totally different perspective when it comes to how the members view California Casualty and what is the best way to approach each individual lead to be successful. Both manager's compliment each other and ultimately are there for us to succeed. 

I was 1 of 4 lucky to be selected and our class immediately became very close. Iron sharpens iron and that has been our mentality. In our first year alone we are bringing some serious numbers to the KC office. 

To be successful here you need to be coachable, have goals, put the time in and consistently strive to be better. If you played sports in college or have the ability to really understand how California Casualty can be a solution to each member's unique situation, you will be successful as a sales rep.

cons: Micro-management is their highest priority providing minimal autonomy to staff. Employees are overworked and unappreciated. title: Claims Adjuster in Phoenix, Arizona
pros: You get time off the phones to work your files, but even that is ending on December 1, 2014, so I can't think of anything that is actually better than the other companies I've ever worked for. Not even the people - they are cliquish and talk badly about new employees, instead of trying to help them. THEY control the show here at this company.
cons:
The #1 worst thing about this company is the systems. For those of us that still have 20-40 years in the working world, it is like stepping back in time by 20 years! Their systems are SO out of date that it's unreal. It's actually very difficult to work here because of it. Also, it says something about their processes, too. What gets done with one click at another company, takes 3-4 bad systems to maneuver through here.

Also, their customers are horrible to deal with! They complain about everything and I don't blame them. This company isn't even up to date on the insurance products that other companies have been offering for years, like rental coverage that actually COVERS today's rental rates and accident forgiveness. You won't see that here. 

The other disappointing factor is the people you work with that have 20-35 years and are a "clique". Managers do not know how to "manage" today's workers - they are still stuck in the 80's! All they need is a good lawsuit to teach them that time has actually been better for the employee and they need to be careful how they treat them. There is a serious seniority gap between those that are new and those that don't have the skills or the ability to be able to leave this company, ie: the managers and their senior employees. And to this point, good luck getting any time off when you are competing with such high seniority. Now I see why there are not a whole lot of people here between the 4-20 year gap - they've all quit! And, I don't know of any other company that does their vacation bidding for the next 6 months; everywhere else I've worked, you bid for the next year, not the next 6 months. We can't even bid for holidays next year because this company doesn't open up their calendars.

The benefits are truly the worst I've ever had in my entire life! Had I known - truly known - how bad it was, I would have never accepted the job at this company! They don't even encourage you to take insurance courses and we had to pay to get our own licenses! The training was absolutely horrible - if you come from another company and did this job before, you will be fine and actually know more about the job than the trainer, who would rather be a fashion designer, I think. But if you're like me and never did insurance before, it is so difficult, especially when the managers disappear for "hours" for their "lunch" or "pedicures", so don't expect any help there.

I don't know how much longer this company can be in business. It seems most of their customers are pushing 100 years old and they pay an arm and a leg for insurance that doesn't cover them like other companies. You don't see a push for new customers and since the company doesn't put any money into their employees, systems, or training, it just seems like this "family owned business" is going to go the way of the world and die a slow death. As for me, I don't plan on being here much longer and if you are wanting to work in a REAL claims environment where things work, go anywhere else but here!

title: Lots of potential to be a great job but management is ruining everything

There is really only one con in this company = management. 50% of the management in the outbound sales department are condescending, sarcastic, overbearing, and make you dread coming into work everyday.  Just last week, everyone was told by managment that non-work related conversations were no longer allowed and you can longer be out of your desk area unless your discussing a work issue. The office is now even more gloomy and negative due to this new mandate. Even the experienced reps get coached and listened to when they actually have more experience than the manager that's listening to them. Everyone is in constant fear of losing their jobs and my coworkers talked about quitting everyday because they are so frustrated with the way things are and the way they get treated.  During my ~4 years as a leader I saw the steady erosion of morale and motivation as a direct result. My ability to support and empower staff was greatly limited due to this.

They say they are pay for performance, but they are not. Bonuses are determined based on a bell-curve and overall performance has little to do with bonus payout.

Additionally, salaries are incredibly low compared to similar companies in similar geographies.

The work environment is not psychologically safe. If you do not share a popular opinion it is not valued or fully heard. Senior leaders greatly lack any form of emotional intelligence.

Advancement is massively challenging. They do not promote; despite doing the work of a senior role you must apply and then you must navigate the political waters and agendas of others; your performance has little to do with where you can go within the organization.

title: Trying to turn an aircraft carrier
pros:
First off,  the company is HUGE (# of employees and office space) so I can only speak to generalities at a high level.

There is a serious movement to bring the organization into the 21st century. One of the few companies that has built entire teams specifically for customer experience and innovation.

Compensation is above average.

Since CanadaLife is one of the few major players in the assurance space, there is a lot of really meaningful work available that can have a nationwide impact.
cons:
First off,  the company is HUGE (# of employees and office space) so I can only speak to generalities at a high level.

The company is in year 3 of a mega culture transformation. The changes at a leadership level have been non-stop, which affects everything from process to direction to system of values.

If we were to create a spectrum defining "ways of working," tech companies and startups would be at one end of the spectrum for 'modern' whereas Canada Life would be at the other end of the spectrum for 'not modern.'

1) Email is the primary tool for too many functions; communication, work management, file sharing and calendar management. Inboxes get out of hand very quickly, information gets buried very quickly, silos are created inadvertently and unnecessary meetings are booked.

2) Lack of diversity at senior levels.

3) Extremely risk averse. Innovation and new ways of working face a constant uphill battle. Many layers of red tape and naysayers.

4) Inefficient org structure. Mirrored teams and roles create blurred lines, duplication of work and inhibits knowledge sharing and co-creation.

Promotions are sometimes drawn out longer than needed.  But if you continue to do a good job and prove yourself you will get it eventually.

title: Collegial with a lots of future potential, but behind the times....
pros:
The draw to join this organization was that they are embarking upon a transformation of their Canadian business.  I knew this would mean interesting and challenging work and change and that has been the case.  

I would say of the many employers I have had in past, there is a genuine interest and concern for employee well-being and work/life balance.  It is a collegial work environment and I am enjoying the people I am working with.  People generally like working here and take a lot of pride in the company.

I feel well compensated for what I do - they are higher on base and lower on variable pay i.e. bonus but that works fine for me.  They have nice staff perks like discounted tickets for Jays, the Aquarium, etc. which is nice.  There is an onsite gym with great classes that costs next to nothing for employees.

The organization has been largely successful to date so is built on a solid foundation.  It is an exciting time to be apart of it.
cons:
The company has been successful to date but are severely behind the times.  They have not invested in basic infrastructure in a significant amount of time which means systems are dated, legacy in nature and home grown, don't 'talk to each other' and very little is integrated and automated.  As a result, there are a ton of inefficiencies and broken processes, largely manual in nature and paper based.  I get the sense this is because there is a big focus on expenses/cost, but they would have been better off to invest incrementally over the years vs. being in the position now where they have to overhaul everything which is hugely expensive.

The average tenure of employees is extremely high relative to anywhere else I have every worked and there is very low turnover.  In some ways that is positive - people like working here, etc. - but on the flip side it contributes to the lack of innovation, efficiency or basically just keeping up with the times.  People don't know what they don't know, so trying to affect change is difficult and can be very frustrating for those driving the change, and for external hires in general who are used to more sophisticated work environments.  There seems to be a lack of awareness of what is going on in the external market and it is an inward looking culture.  

Senior leaders make all the decisions and don't empower those below them to do so.  The plan is to change that which is good.  There is a strong sentiment of 'management' vs. 'staff', which is hierarchical and  antiquated.  In addition there is a lack of communication on a regular basis to the employee population about basic things like the annual strategic objectives/goals, messages around the need to change, etc. as well as messaging to the outside about what it's like to be apart of the company and the things are doing.  It is not clear with the masses what the case for change/transformation is, people don't understand the vision, etc.  Information seems to be guarded/held at the top and is not shared, even though at times I don't understand why they are not sharing certain things.  As a result, it feels patriarchal.  The Communication strategy and practices needed to be overhauled.

My closing comment is that there is a lot of potential for this organization, which is why I joined.  It has been very successful to date but there is recognition of the need to change and adapt which is compelling.  It will be a journey but there will be a huge amount of capacity released if we reduce manual/administrative work, which will in turn create more interesting and meaningful jobs.

title: Unstructured, disjoint, and unconcerned thereof
pros: There were a multitude of good co-workers, good people who placed the work that they were doing ahead of themselves, and did whatever it took for their department despite a lack of recognition or encouragement, and sometimes even discouragement from management. There were many staff members who took client interests to heart, and provided service that was courteous, effective, and genuine. There were managers who provided encouragement and empowerment, and were a genuine pleasure to work under.
cons:
Having listed many positives above, the negatives unfortunately outweigh these factors. I think the best way to understand this company and the other reviews posted is to be aware that its operation as a whole is very disjoint and piecemeal. Acquired subsidiaries and individual departments all operate more or less independent of one another. That is not to say that the parent company as a whole does not install company wide initiatives, values, and directives, but on the whole interpretation of and compliance with these measures are not practiced nor enforced effectively. With that in mind, the above rating, and all others are more affected by the individual department in which a given employee works, rather than the company as a whole. 

The employee experience within any given department is most affected by the quality of the leadership within that area, and the overall company provides little or no impact to an individual's day-to-day experience. Many leaders within the company possess and air of superiority, and a privileged mindset in that they feel entitled to perks not afforded to staff, such as additional breaks, increased time for socialization, and working from home at their leisure. They generally regard staff as a means to an end, and not as individuals with concerns and aspirations, and take pleasure in pointing out flaws. They feel no responsibility to their staff, and as such, staff members feel unappreciated and unsupported.

Furthering this feeling is a lack of competency in many managers in ensuring the department as a whole meets targets and obligations. Many manager's abilities do not extend beyond the repetition of buzzwords, and lack an adequate understanding of how their department functions, what it needs to accomplish, and what it is accomplishing currently. Many state that they do not know what is going on in their department, and rely on feedback from staff to know if targets are not being met. In some areas, this has led to non-compliance with court orders, and lengthy delays in freezing assets in cases of bankruptcy. Managers are not being held accountable for these and other shortcomings, and the negative results are often transferred to front-line staff.
